thread.title: 'Obamacare Is the Law of the Land' After Trump Yanks Health Care Bill
thread.title_full: 'Obamacare Is the Law of the Land' After Trump Yanks Health Care Bill

title: 'Obamacare Is the Law of the Land' After Trump Yanks Health Care Bill
text:
'Obamacare Is the Law of the Land' After Trump Yanks Health Care Bill By Ben Fractenberg and Nicole Levy | March 24, 2017 4:26pm | Updated March 24, 2017 4:27pm View Full Caption Ben Fractenberg 
MIDTOWN — Obamacare is still the "law of the land," after Trump pulled the Republican health care bill Friday right before the House was ready to vote on the bill, officials said. 
The bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act was pulled at the last minute after dozens of conservative and moderate Republicans came out publicly against it, with 33 vowing to vote no and nine with concerns, leaving the party with the prospect of a humiliating defeat. 
"We're going to be living with Obamacare for the forseeable future," Speaker Paul Ryan said after the bill was pulled, "Obamacare is the law of the land. It's going to remain the law of the land." 
"We came really close today, but we came up short," Ryan added it, "This is a disappointing day for us." 
“House Republicans finally realized that the bill they have proposed does not pass muster with the American people," said Congresswoman Carolyn Maloney, who represents parts of Manhattan and Queens, in a statement. "This bill would have ripped away health insurance from 24 million Americans, increased premiums and imposed an age tax on people over 50 years old," she added, referring to the findings of the Congressional Budget Office. 
The bill, amended to appease the conservative House Freedom Caucus, would also have eliminated "essential health benefits," such as maternity care and prescription drug coverage. 
But Republicans will continue to push for benefits cuts, in the interest of trimming the federal budget deficit, she warned. 
“I will continue to do everything I can to protect the significant progress we have made since the Affordable Care Act (ACA) was signed into law seven years ago," Maloney said.
